question: Shit!
answer: Truman! Truman! Stop! Come down now! No!

question: Why? What's there?
answer: Nothing's there. It's the same as this. Come down, please! I told you to stay close. Don't ever leave my sight again. You gotta know your limitations. You could've been washed away by the tide.

question: Gimme a copy of "The Sydney Morning Herald". Thanks anyway. I want to be an explorer ...like Magellan. ...okay, okay, let's call it what it is... I'm not gonna lie to you...life insurance is death insurance...you just gotta ask yourself two questions...one, in the event of your death, will anyone experience financial loss?...and two, do you care? Hold on will ya? This's no good. Lumps all drownings together. I need drownings broken down by category. ...just think about what I've been saying and lemme...hello?... Can you connect me with directory inquiries in Sydney, Australia? ...er, yes. Do you have a listing for a Lauren Powers... ...nothing listed?...what about a Sylvia Powers...nothing? Thanks...
answer: How's it goin', Truman?

question: Not bad. I just won the State Lottery.
answer: Good. Good.

question: Tyrone, what if I said I didn't want meatball today?
answer: I'd ask for identification. Hold on, Truman. I got somethin' to show ya. The flagship of Christoforo...our Genoese navigator, huh? I know you love this like me.

question: Not me. You got the wrong man.
answer: See ya tomorrow, Truman.

question: ...this isn't about insurance, this is about the great variable - when will death occur? Could be a week, a month, a year. Could happen today...A sunbather, minding his own business, gets stabbed in the heart by the tip of a runaway beach umbrella...No way you can guard against that kinda thing, no way at all...
answer: Hey, Burbank, I got a bridge-buyer in Stapleton I need you to cloes by four.

question: Stapleton on Staten Island?
answer: You know another one?

question: I can't do it.
answer: A half hour across the bay. Sea air. Do you good.

question: No, I... ...I got an appointment uptown.
answer: This is a sure thing. They're upping our quota. You need this.

question: I got it free with the tune-up. You missed a section.
answer: Do they hurt?

question: I was afraid I'd seize up during cross. One of the keys kept sticking.
answer: Is he gonna take the stand?

question: No point. Two eye witnesses saw him near the dumpster where they found the legs. You gonna eat before you leave?
answer: I'll get something out.

question: Did something happen today?
answer: What could happen?

question: What could happen?
answer: Ouch. Whose nuts were those?

question: Mine. I gotta get out, Marlon.
answer: Yeah? Outta what?

question: Outta my job, outta Queens...out!
answer: Outta your job? What the hell's wrong with your job? You gotta great job. You gotta desk job. I'd kill for a desk job. Sonofabitch.

question: It doesn't mean anything.
answer: Nothing means anything. Try stocking vending machines for a living. My biggest decision of the day is whether the Almond Joys look better next to the Snickers or the Baby Ruths.

question: I gotta get out.
answer: Sure and go where?

question: Australia.
answer: No shit. Where is Australia exactly? Near England?

question: See here, this is Queens. All the way round here, Australia. You can't get any further away before you start coming back. Y'know, there're still places in Australia where no human being has ever set foot.
answer: So when are you leaving?

question: It's not that simple. Takes money, planning. You can't just up and go. Oh, I'm gonna do it, don't worry about that. I just gotta move slow. Pick a moment. Bonus time's just around the corner. Soon as I get a retaining wall built on the back of the house I can start thinking about selling up...and I'll be gone. Up and away on that big steel bird. I'm going, don't you worry about that.
answer: I never knew anybody who got out.

question: Tick-fucking-tock. That's the fucking problem, Marlon. I'm thirty-four. I'm older than Jesus Christ. Where do the dreams go, Marlon?
answer: You win.

question: I'm serious. Where do the dreams go?
answer: They're still there. Just buried under what we settled for.

question: You really think it could've dropped off an airliner?
answer: Sure. It's halogen. You oughta report it. You coming for a drink?

question: I can't tonight. I'm sorry! I'm sorry!
answer: What are you doing? Come to bed.

question: I figure we could scrape together eight thousand.
answer: Oh. God, everytime you and Marlon--

question: --We could bum around the world for a year on that.
answer: And then what, Truman? We'd be back to where we were five years ago. You're talking like a teenager.

question: Maybe I feel like a teenager. Meryl, it'd be an adventure.
answer: We said we'd try for a baby. Isn't that enough of an adventure?

question: That can wait. I want to get away. See some of the world. Explore.
answer: You want to be an explorer? You mean like all the other great explorers from Queens? You don't even have a passport, Truman. I bet you don't even know how to get one. This'll pass. Everybody thinks like this now and then. Come to bed.

question: Daddy!!...Daddy!!... Daddy... Hey, stop! Stop!! Two, four, oh, six. Outta the way! Outta the way! I'm sorry! I'm sorry! No harm done! No harm done!
answer: What're you doing? The man told you there's no such bus.

question: He's lying. Two, four, oh, six was definitely the number. I never believed he was dead.
answer: C'mon, Truman, a lotta times they don't find a body. You know what the currents are like in that water.

question: You had to see his face when that wave hit. He wasn't scared Marion. It was like he was expecting it, waiting for it. He knew it was coming.
answer: Why would he fake it? He's not Elvis Presley.

question: You know what was really strange about today? An old woman with a little dog and a businessman, walking in opposite directions on the sidewalk, both react like clockwork. They force him onto a bus against his will, a bus that doesn't normally stop outside my building. And when I'm giving chase, the bus never makes another stop and I get the feeling that the traffic and the pedestrians are working together to make sure I never catch up with it.
answer: Oh, so now it's also the pedestrians and the buses and the cars? What are you saying, the entire population of Lower Manhattan is conspiring to stop you finding out that your father staged his death to pursue a life as a street person? Oh yeah, that makes sense.

question: You think I imagined it, don't you?
answer: I think you're missing your dad. The anniversary was yesterday, wasn't it? You got sand in your cuffs.

question: Maybe you're right. If only the old woman hadn't left her dog behind.
answer: Don't you dare go in. Truman. I just got her off to sleep.

question: It was Dad. I swear.
answer: Well, the next time he shows up. bring him over. Until then, I'm not saying a word about this to Mom and neither are you.

question: If it wasn't him, it was his twin. Can you think of a reason he'd want to hide from us? I was seven years old!
answer: But you're here and he's not. Has it really taken you this long to invent a story to ease your conscience?

question: I'm telling you he's alive!
answer: And I'm telling you he's fish food!

question: What're you doing out here?
answer: Fixing the mower.

question: Your sister called. She was worried about you.
answer: I saw my father on State Street dressed as a homeless man.

question: I kept seeing my brother for years after he died.
answer: What do you want?

question: I made macaroni.
answer: I gotta go out. About a replacement... ...mower blade.

question: Hi. Lauren, right?
answer: No.

question: Look. I was wonder--
answer: --I can't go out with you.

question: I haven't asked you yet.
answer: Well when you do, that's my answer. I'm sorry. It's not up to me.

question: Why, you married? I'm not asking you to have my children, just a pizza. How about Saturday?
answer: No.

question: Friday?
answer: Now.

question: Right now? We got finals.
answer: If we don't go now, it won't happen. Well, what do you want to do?

question: I never knew this place existed. Come on! Come on! It's wonderful!
answer: I...I can't.

question: That's right. Oh, God, I'm sorry.
answer: Why? You've got nothing to be sorry about. Has someone been talking to you?

question: Get me out of here. I don't want to be here.
answer: What are you talking about? Lauren! Lauren!

question: In a minute someone's going to come and stop me talking to you.
answer: Who? There's no one around.

question: You remember when you were a little boy, you stood up in class and said you wanted to be an explorer like Magellan. And your teacher, Sister Olivia said, "You're too late, Truman. There's nothing left to explore." And all the other kids laughed. And you sat down.
answer: How do you know about that?

question: It doesn't matter. You've forgotten about that boy, Truman. You got scared. Just because something happens, doesn't mean you can't take another chance in your life.
answer: I don't understand.

question: There isn't much time. Just listen. Everybody's pretending Truman. Everybody but you. Look at that project. You think anybody lives there? It's all for you, Truman. A show. The eyes are everywhere.
answer: Eyes? Where?

question: Everywhere, disguised...Truman, they're going to fill your head with lies. You've got to make yourself deaf, you understand? When you're afraid the most, it means you're on the right track. Trust that boy. Promise me you'll do that? I told you, Truman!
answer: Hey!

question: I've got something to tell you, Sis.
answer: I've got something to tell you too.

question: I'm going to Australia.
answer: Mom's real sick.

question: I have an appointment at, er...Diamond Enterprises. What're they doing? Just tell me what the hell's going on? Like fuck! What're they doing? You don't tell me, I'll get you investigated! --I know. You ever been into the AMT Building?
answer: Not since they begun reconstruction. What're you doing with that?

question: I'm going to visit a site.
answer: What for?

question: Because I never do.
answer: That's why we got adjusters.

question: You got a problem with me going?
answer: I got a problem with you not doing your job, Burbank. You already screwed up once this week.

question: Let me worry about that.
answer: 680 West 89th.

question: Small world. You don't remember? Two days ago I gave you my meatball sandwich in the park. You were in a wheelchair. Same sneakers. A miracle! Marlon. I've gotta talk to you.
answer: Truman! Sorry, I'm up against it today.

question: I've fallen over something, Marlon. Something to do with my Dad. I think.
answer: Are you okay? You look like shit.

question: It's big, Marlon. You wouldn't believe who's in on it.
answer: In on what?

question: There's no point trying to show you, they cover their tracks too well. But I've been going into a lotta strange buildings, seeing a lotta familiar faces, y'know what I mean?
answer: Something's definitely in the air. My last delivery, a kid got crushed to death. tilting a vending machine. They won't even let me take the rest of the day off.

question: Do it, anyway. I'm deadly serious. Marlon. We can't talk here. I'm being followed.
answer: Who?

question: I don't know. They look just like regular people. But I've been writing down numbers - license plates, taxi numbers, ID numbers - the same ones keep cropping up over and over.
answer: Is someone leanin' on you, Tru? Cos I got some friends here, they owe me. We can lean back. Is he one of them?

question: I don't know. Could be. One thing's certain. The key is spontoneity. Be unpredictable. They can't stand that. That's why we've got to get outta here. Can you come with me?
answer: Christ, Truman. You're gonna get both our asses fired. Where're we going?

question: Fear? Doubt? Is that what you have trouble watching? Perhaps you don't like watching yourself.
answer: Why don't you two wait outside?

question: He's jumped the rails, Moses, that's all. We'll get him back on.
answer: You know why they're so nervous. The birth of Truman's child is going to double revenue. For God's sake don't let him upstage you. You've been grooming a successor.

question: He's not ready.
answer: Him or you?

question: You can't pull him back in without me. He's just acting out of character.
answer: What if he's in character? What if he's starting to act in character at last? Have you ever considered that?

question: What're we doing here, Truman?
answer: This is where it started.

question: Where what started?
answer: Things. Things that don't fit. Loose threads. False steps. Slips of the tongue.

question: Make sense, Truman. You going religious on me?
answer: My father didn't want me to see what was over here. Whatever it was, it's gone now. I never shoulda listened to him that day. I knew it was wrong. There were a hundred people on the beach that day. Everybody knew what was going on except me.

question: I don't want to put you down but why would anybody go to all this trouble over you?
answer: Maybe I've been mistaken for somebody else. A couple of years ago, I tried to get hold of a copy of Time Magazine. The week before an ad said, "Next Week A guy with the same name as me in Time Magazine. It ain't a common name so I looked out for it. But the day it came out, every newstand was sold out. No library had it. I even wrote off for a back-issue. Never seen a copy to this day. Maybe I'm being set up for something. You ever feel like that, Marlon? Like your whole life has been building to something?

question: A coincidence. Haven't you ever heard of a coincidence?
answer: I'm a walking coincidence. I can't count 'em. No something's happening, Marlon. I've got to get to the bottom of it.

question: Of what?! Why're you doing this to yourself?
answer: I'm scared, Marlon. I'm as scared as hell. But I've never felt more alive. It's just like she said.

question: Who?
answer: It doesn't matter. She was too beautiful for here. Can you lend me some money? A hundred bucks.

question: All I got on me is the takings from the machines. Why do you need it?
answer: I'm going away for a while.

question: I'm going away for a while.
answer: What's going on, Truman? You're not yourself.

question: Maybe you just don't know me very well.
answer: We could do it right here, like we used to.

question: Lemme go to the bathroom.
answer: Don't be too long.

question: Er, yes... No, no I'm not. I wanna book a flight to Australia.
answer: Where exactly?

question: Australia.
answer: Where in Australia? What city?

question: Sorry, Sydney. Sydney, Australia. That's right.
answer: For how many?

question: One.
answer: When do you want to leave, remembering, of course, that you do lose a day on the way there?

question: Today.
answer: I'm sorry. I don't have anything for a week.

question: A week.
answer: It's the busy season.

question: You sure you're not trying to keep me here? You are a travel agent, aren't you? Your job is to help people travel, not keep 'em where they are. Or maybe you're a different kind of agent, Doris?
answer: I do have a fabulous rate on a cruise ship departing for Australia tomorrow. But you wouldn't want to do that.

question: Why wouldn't I?
answer: I thought you were in a hurry.

question: That's right.
answer: You want to book the flight?

question: You were expecting me, weren't you?
answer: It's non-refundable.

question: Can we contain him long enough?
answer: Why go to all the trouble?

question: He believes she has the answer.
answer: Why not just tell him she's dead?

question: "Yours truly..." You spell "truly" "l...y" or "e...l...y"?
answer: Where the hell have you been, Burbank? What the hell's going on?

question: That's what I'd like to know, Lawrence. I was just about to resign. Isn't that a laugh? I just realized there's nothing to resign from, is there?
answer: Listen, don't bother with the resignation. Just get the fuck outta here.

question: Why're you all pretending? Huh? What is this a front for? Why aren't I in on the joke? Was I away that day?! I'm talking to you! Who am I?!
answer: You better get outta here or I'm calling Security.

question: Say my name or I'll smash its head open. Say my name! Say my name! You know my name! Say it! I mean it! I'm ready to do it! What's my name?!! This is your last chance! What...is...my...name?! See that car way down there? I bet it's a Suburu station wagon. I predict the next four cars will be a white Honda Civic, a blue and white Dodge Dart with the front hubcap missing, a Volkswagon Beetle with a dented fender and a motorcycle. There's the Honda...the Dodge...here comes the dented Beetle... Look, damn you!
answer: Where's the motorcycle?

question: Don't you want to know how I did that? Maybe you already know. Is that it?
answer: Where have you been? I've been calling you all day.

question: Have you been concerned, Meryl? Nice name. "Meryl". I always liked it.
answer: Nice of you to say so after eight years.

question: Actress's name, isn't it? What's your real name?
answer: Oh, God. What's got into you?

question: Take a break. Meryl I know.
answer: I invited Marlon and Rita for a barbeque Sunday. I thought I'd make my potato salad. Remind me...

question: Drop it, I said. It's over.
answer: ...we need more charcoal.

question: Shut up!
answer: I'm gonna take a shower.

question: No. We're going for a drive.
answer: What?!

question: For years I've been saying I want to go some place, well now I'm ready to go. Let's just jump in the car and go. I thought maybe, Atlantic City.
answer: You hate gambling.

question: That's right. I do, don't I?
answer: So why do you wanna go?

question: So much traffic, this time of day. Does that strike you as peculiar? Look at them. You believe they're fighting? I don't believe it. Why don't you slug him, really make it authentic? Blocked at every turn. Beautifully synchronized, don't you agree?
answer: You blaming me for the traffic?

question: Should I?
answer: You've never been on this road before. You don't know what it's like.

question: That's true. We could be stuck here for hours. Could be like this all the way to Atlantic City.
answer: What the hell are you doing?

question: You're right. Let's go back. I'm sorry. I don't know what got into me.
answer: Would you please slow down, Truman? Truman, that was the turnoff!

question: I've changed my mind again. What's Maine like this time of year?! I've never been to Maine. Or let's just see where the road takes us.
answer: Let me out, Truman. You're not right in the head. You wanna destroy yourself, you do it on your own!

question: He's so close! It's tantilizing!
answer: You want to pull him over?

question: No police. Not yet. We shadow him. We don't want him to panic.
answer: He's trying to outrun the traffic.

question: Let me get you some help, Truman. You're not well.
answer: Why do you want to have a child with me? You can't stand me.

question: That's not true.
answer: Don't lie to me! Tell me what's happening?!

question: I thought you knew everything. What could I tell you?
answer: You're part of this, aren't you?!

question: Truman, you're scaring me!
answer: No, you're scaring me, Meryl! Stop this now or I kill your leading lady. I know you can hear me.

question: Do something...
answer: Who are you talking to?!

question: You're the one talking to the walls!
answer: No. You said, "Do something." Who were you talking to? I swear I'll kill you, if you don't tell me. How could you buy this damn thing when you know he drowned in front of me?! You have any idea what it's like to drown?

question: Truman, stop it! Don't let him do it!
answer: I'll kill her! Right on time. Cops must be telepathic. Damn! Stay where you are or I'll kill her!

question: People know who I am, my every move, complete strangers know my name. Even when there's no one around, I feel the eyes on me.
answer: I was in the bank today. The Federal on Lewis. A clerk was talking about somebody named Truman messing with her baby. Is that the stranger you're talking about?

question: No. No. I've never seen her before. I know you already think I'm going out of my mind but I genuinely believe the world revolves around me somehow. Everybody seems to be in on it.
answer: It's a lot of world for one man. You sure that's not wishful thinking, you wishing you'd made something more of yourself? Christ, Truman, who hasn't sat on the John and had an imaginary interview with Barbara Walters? Who hasn't wanted to be somebody?

question: That's just it. I think I am somebody.
answer: I used to dream all my friends and family got together in a hotel room, thinking of ways to fuck me up.

question: Sometimes I think it's in my head, sometimes I think it's for real.
answer: Tru, we've known each other since before we could get a hard-on. The only way we ever made it through high school was cheating off each other's test papers. Jesus, they were identical. I always liked that, because whatever the answer was, we was right together and we was wrong together. The only night either of us ever spent in jail, we spent together and I wet myself but you never told anyone. I was best man at your wedding and my brother was best man at my wedding and you didn't talk to me for a month over that and I didn't blame you because you've been more of a brother to me than he's ever been. And I never shoulda let my Goddam father talk me into that. I know things haven't worked out for either of us like we used to sit up on Freemont Street all night and dream they would. We all let opportunities pass us by, none of us asks for the dance as often as we should. I know that feeling when it's like everything's slipping away and you don't want to believe it so you look for answers someplace else. But, well, the point is, I would gladly step in front of traffic for you.

question: Welcome to week seventeen hundred and sixty eight of "Truman" and there can scarcely have been a more momentous week in the show's history. I'm your host, Michael Conners, and this is a special edition of "Tru Talk", the forum where we discuss and analyze recent events with the show's award-winning creator and producer, Christof. I remind viewers that as this is a living history, it is our practise to keep the image of Truman on screen at all times. Welcome.
answer: Thank you.

question: Before we start taking calls, the huge surge in ratings over the last few days, how do you hope to sustain that audience now that Truman appears to have reconciled himself, returned to "normal"?
answer: Ratings have never been our primary goal. I imagine we'll lose those voycurs only interested in witnessing Truman's latest torment. However I'm certain our core audience will remain loyal.

question: But recent events have been so dramatic, it does raise the perennial question. What keeps us watching one man twenty-four hours a day - eating, sleeping, working, sitting for hours in contemplation?
answer: It has to be the reality. We've become increasingly frustrated watching actors give us phony emotions, bored with pyrotechnics and special effects. While the world he inhabits is counterfeit, there's nothing fake about Truman himself. No scripts. no cue cards. It's not always Shakespeare but it's genuine. That's how he can support an entire channel.

question: A window onto the human condition?
answer: I prefer to think of it as a mirror. Not only does he give us a glimpse of the truth, he gives us a glimpse of ourselves.

question: But how do you account for the popularity of those eight hours a day when Truman sleeps?
answer: We find many viewers leave him on all night for comfort. Haven't you ever watched your child or your lover sleep?

question: Let's go to some of those viewers' calls. Charlotte, North Carolina, for Christof. You're on, caller. Go ahead.
answer: Thank you. I don't believe so. Not now. He tested his world, as we all do at certain times, and eventually it passed the test. You have to understand, he is a man made-for-TV, the world he occupies his only frame of reference. No, for him to come even this close to the truth is a remarkable testament to his instincts.

question: Sacramento, California, you're on "Tru Talk".
answer: Working on "Truman" has always been a huge commitment for an actor, not just in terms of separation from friends and family, but since Truman essentially drives the plot, it's a never-ending improvisation. Recent events have raised the pressure but also the prestige.

question: Of course Truman has always been very much in on casting.
answer: As with our own lives, the only people he can't cast are his family. Otherwise he has final approval, able to elevate an extra into a lead role as was the case with his only real friend, Marlon, or alternatively relegate a star to a bit player.

question: Istanbul, Turkey, you're on with world-renowned videographer, Christof.
answer: Who can? In his entire life, forty-two minutes. A technical fault in 1978 accounts for most of that time. The remainder generally results from blindspots, in the early days, when Truman would stray out of range of our cameras.

question: The Hague for Christof...The Hague?...lost them. Amagansett, Long Island, you're on "Tru Talk".
answer: I believe that to be so. I often feel the only difference between Truman's life and our own is that his is being more thoroughly documented. We all play our allotted roles-- --He can leave at any time. If his was more than just a vague ambition, if he were absolutely determined to discover the truth, there's no way we could prevent him. I think what really distresses you, caller, is that ultimately he prefers the comfort of his "cell"-- Do I know you, caller? Your voice sounds familiar.

question: Recording a human life from birth to death, that's still the intention? You still believe Truman has more to contribute?
answer: More than ever. By unwittingly allowing us to witness his struggles, he's constantly forcing us to evaluate our own lives. He gives us hope.

question: Let's take another call. London, England you're on "Tru Talk".
answer: What are you looking for?

question: What are you looking for?
answer: He was premature, wasn't he?

question: Only by two weeks.
answer: Curious even then? Like he couldn't wait to get started?

question: His eagerness to leave his mother's womb also meant he was the one selected.
answer: What was it like, the first show?

question: The ultimate live television. In competition with five other unwanted pregnancies - the casting of a show determined by an air date - he was the one who arrived on cue.
answer: Is it true what you said...on the show tonight? About letting him go if he wanted it badly enough. Would you really do that?

question: It won't come to that. I hope we've got fresh extras.
answer: The rotation was made this morning.

question: ...Ready two. Go to two. And back to the medium. ...and wide...
answer: Could we have picked a bigger loser if we tried?

question: That loser pays our salary.
answer: He's given up on himself again.

question: Who cares? Makes life easier for us. He is what he is.
answer: When did he start sleeping like that?

question: About the time Meryl left.
answer: Is that the best shot we can get?

question: What's to see?
answer: What happened to the room?

question: He started to reorganize. I was going to call you. But half-way through, he gave up and fell asleep.
answer: I want to check the set-ups for tomorrow's insurance convention. Give me a shot from his wedding band.

question: He took it off.
answer: Why is he so still? He's too still. Isolate the audio in the cans and amplify. Give me a preview. An ECU on his torso. Phone him. He didn't drink tonight? No pills? Hang up! Get Marlon over there.

question: We tell him the truth. We're making a movie.
answer: We'll get him on this next sweep.

question: What have we missed?
answer: It's just a matter of time.

question: Trust that boy... We're not watching the sea.
answer: Why would we?

question: Sweep the harbor.
answer: That's him!

question: Fire a warning.
answer: Jesus! God! Is he out of his mind?

question: Pull back. How long will another chopper take?
answer: By the time we pick up the pilots, too long.

question: We have to stop him for his own good. Turn him back with the elements.
answer: There's no rescue boat in the area. He won't know what to do.
